h3. Problem Definition
When many ancestors are included in the rest api call to create child pages, confluence uses the first one

h3. Suggested Solution
Confluence should use the last ancestors in order to set the parent if more than one are submitted. Using ancestors[0] seems counter intuitive as other parts of the REST API return ordered collections of ancestors.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45721].
{panel}
h3. Problem statement

With Collaborative Editing enabled, all users are sharing the same draft. However, if a single user wants to leave the editor and discard his own changes, he doesn't have the option to do so unless:
 # He manually removes his changes.
 # He clicks on the 'Undo' button in the page until his changes are gone.

At present, he can only either remove everyone's changes or keep everyone's changes along with his own. Also, when you "Save and Close" Undo button will not remember the previous action, thus, Undo button will not disregard the changes.
h3. Suggestion

Provide an extra button or option ("Discard my changes") whereby the user can discard his own changes.
fields.summary: Allow users to discard their own changes with Collaborative Editing

{panel:title=Update March 6th, 2017}
Hi everyone,

Thank you for your patience while affected by this issue. Although a number of us on the Confluence development team use the LastPass chrome extension, our attempts to investigate the root cause of this issue have been hampered by not being able to reproduce it ourselves.

We have noticed that LastPass' [release notes|https://lastpass.com/upgrade.php?fromwebsite=1&releasenotes=1] for version 4.1.40 mention fixing an issue that _"impacted a handful of sites"_.

Could anyone who is still impacted by this issue please check the version of LastPass they have installed in Chrome? Typing {{chrome://extensions}} in your browser's address bar will show the version numbers for extensions you have installed.

If this issue has persisted for you and you are using LastPass 4.1.40 or later, please reach out to us again via [support.atlassian.com|https://support.atlassian.com/].

Thanks,
 Edith
{panel}
h3. Summary

Several customers with the LastPass extension enabled in Chrome are reporting that they are unable to save Confluence pages, the UI returns the error *"Unable to communicate with server. Saving is not possible at the moment"*.

!abc.png|thumbnail!
h3. Steps to reproduce.
 # Try to save a Confluence page in Chrome with the LastPass extension enabled, however, it happens only in specific situations and do not affect all customers.

h3. Workaround

Use a different browser or disable the extension.
fields.summary: Unable to save Confluence page in Chrome (caused by LastPass extension)
Make possible to grant same rights as existing user account.

h3. Problem Definition
Currently there is no way to make a copy of a page and have the copied page retain two things: 
# The page history of the original page
# The same URL used by the original page

h3. Suggested Solution
Implement a solution that copies the page history of a page to the new copy and also ensures that all links pointing to the original page are re-routed to the new copy.

h3. Why this is important
In certain situations, it is necessary to make a copy of a page to add the content, but the page cannot be copied back due to attachment names changing. 
Providing a way to correctly migrate the data to a new page with page history and little disruption to links would help fix this pain point. 

h3. Workaround 
At this time there is not a workaround.
fields.summary: When copying a page include page history and page links

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45647].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently Confluence displays all existing groups in a list with check boxes to add or remove the user from those groups listed (membership). When the directory is "Read Only, with Local Groups", we are not able to modify the membership related to the external directory, so if there are a lot of external groups, it's tough to manage their *local* memberships (local groups).

h3. Suggested Solution
List only the Local Groups with the check box to add/remove membership, and in a separate list box, show the membership that comes from the external directory without the check box, since it's *read only*.

h3. Why this is important
There's no reason to allow changes of the membership from the external directory when the directory is *Read Only, with Local Groups* and we cannot change the external membership. If the user has a lot of membership or if the directory synchronises a lot of groups, it's really tough to manage the *local* membership only.
fields.summary: Improve User Membership Page When Directory is Read Only with Local Groups

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45641].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

When anonymous access is enabled a record is written to the space_permissions table.  This record does not include a name in the permgroupname field.  This causes the following record to be written continuously to the {{atlassian-confluence.log}}:
{code:java}
Could not find group configured with USE permission: null{code}
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Start Confluence
 # Enable anonymous access in 'global permissions'
 # Synchronize with LDAP in the User Directories section of the admin console

h3. Expected Results

No message is written to the logs regarding this newly created group for anonymous access
h3. Actual Results

The logs continually show:
{code:java}
INFO [http-nio-8090-exec-14] [atlassian.confluence.user.DefaultUserAccessor] getUsersWithConfluenceAccess Could not find group configured with USE permission: null{code}
h3. Notes

In the example provided, this message appears almost 59,000 times in the course of 24 hours.  This is obviously junking up the logs with unnecessary messages.  We would like either the message not to be written to the logs at all, or add a *permgroupname* such as 'anonymous' to the *spacepermissions* table. 
h3. Workaround
 # You can suppress the message by [Configuring Logging|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Configuring+Logging] 
 # Adding a name directly to the *spacepermissions* group table in the *permgroupnames* field.  This will need to be redone if anonymous access is turned off and back on again or if Confluence is restarted.
fields.summary: Enabling anonymous access causes unnecessary messages in the logs

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45632].
  {panel}

The Confluence editor has always behaved in the worst possible way when a session expires – namely, it provides no hint that anything is wrong, until it's time to save, when you're redirected to the login page and lose all your work.

Some developers might consider losing customer data under normal circumstances a hideous bug, but no, it was resolved as "won't fix due to limited demand" on -CONF-29379-.

What's new is that Synchrony behaves even _worse_ than the old editor. When a session expires mid-edit, as one types, Synchrony still displays a 'Saving changes' message:

!synchrony_saving.png!

then replaced by a 'Changes saved' message when one stops typing:

!synchrony_saved.png!

But this is a filthy lie, as can be seen if one watches the developer console. The changes aren't being saved:

!confedit_errors.png!

When one finally clicks 'Update', one just gets a spinner and nothing is saved.
h2. Steps to Replicate
 # Load up Chrome and edit any page (assuming Synchrony enabled)
 # Hit F12 to open the developer panel, go to the 'Applications' tab and view the page's cookies:
 !conf_cookies.png!
 # Delete the JSESSIONID and 'seraph.confluence' cookies to simulate a session timeout with no 'remember me'.
 # Continue editing. The editor will keep reporting 'Changes saved' despite obviously being unable to.
  

Some Q&A:
h2. This must be wrong. Doesn't the editor display a warning when it can't save a draft?

Confluence's editor displays a nice 'Error saving draft. No draft has been saved' message if it _loses connection_ with the server. If it merely gets 403 errors, it continues happily pretending to save.
h2. If this bug is so terrible, why have I never encountered it?

Because normally developers tick 'Remember me' when logging in. Also, the chances of having an editor open at the point of session expiration (1h) is moderately low.
h2. Why don't users tick 'Remember me'?

Because it's unticked by default, and somewhat cryptic to the uninitiated.

Also, some SSO systems like Okta work by storing users' credentials for them, providing an alternative login screen (e.g. [Okta SWA|https://support.okta.com/help/articles/Knowledge_Article/28328856-Overview-of-Managing-Apps-and-SSO]), and logging in on behalf of users. Okta users in particular never get to set the 'Remember me' checkbox.
h2. Why isn't 'Remember me' ticked by default?

You tell me.
fields.summary: Synchrony editor loses content despite saying 'Changes saved' when session expires

The current implementation of *DEBUG* (or *ALL*) level is set to the class *{{com.atlassian.confluence.mail}}* doesn't log any helpful information for troubleshooting purposes or simple consulting of emails sent by Confluence.
 Here is an example of the logged message when a page is created in a space where the user is a watcher:

 
{code:java}
2016-12-08 11:03:45,957 DEBUG [NotificationSender:thread-2] [confluence.mail.embed.ThreadLocalMimeBodyPartRecorder] record Recorded DataSources with names [page-icon,com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.confluence-email-resources_view-page-email-adg-footer-item_icon,com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.confluence-email-resources_add-comment-to-content-email-adg-footer-item_icon,com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.confluence-like_view-email-adg-content-item_icon,avatar_909dc5ca9d66d2392b9d7bb6d625385f,footer-desktop-logo,footer-mobile-logo].
 2016-12-08 11:03:46,000 DEBUG [NotificationSender:thread-2] [atlassian.confluence.mail.BotocssMailContentProcessor] process Botocss is about to inject styles in to the email.
 2016-12-08 11:03:46,041 DEBUG [NotificationSender:thread-2] [atlassian.confluence.mail.BotocssMailContentProcessor] apply Pruning selected styles from the email.

{code}
If the user is mentioned or other notifications event is triggered and the email is sent successfully, the same messages are logged. This is very confusing for troubleshooting purposes since we cannot determine the action that triggered the email nor the users involved.
h3. Suggested Solution

The mail logging system could be implemented as it currently is in JIRA. After enabling the *DEBUG* level to the *atlassian-jira-outgoing-mail.log*, this is an example of the logged message after the email is sent:

 
{code:java}
2016-12-09 18:40:00,457 DEBUG [] Sending mailitem To='usermail' Subject='(JEP-3) test' From='null' FromName='System Administrator (JIRA)' Cc='null' Bcc='null' ReplyTo='null' InReplyTo='null' MimeType='text/html' Encoding='UTF-8' Multipart='javax.mail.internet.MimeMultipart@1625fac' MessageId='null' ExcludeSubjectPrefix=false' anonymous Mail Queue Service Message was sent with Message-Id <JIRA.10012.1479403314000.1.1481316000418@Atlassian.JIRA>

{code}
h3. Why this is important

This is important for both the customers and the support service to troubleshooting the email system.
h3. Workaround 

There is no known workaround for this issue.
fields.summary: As an Administrator I want more information to be logged when DEBUG level is set for email class

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45518].

h3. Problem Definition

In some situations, it would be useful to choose between OR/AND condition when filtering tasks by label in the Task Report Macro. For example, if the user wants to pull only tasks that have two specific labels at the same time, not one OR another, it would be useful to have this option.
h3. Suggested Solution

Insert a check box in the Task Report Macro configuration with the option to use AND condition instead of OR.
h3. Why this is important

Right now, if the user wants to pull only tasks that share more than one label, they need to create another one just to reflect that condition. If you are working with a large set of tasks, this could become practically impossible.
 
h3. Workaround 

Add another label to the tasks to indicate that they should be pulled from the Task Report Macro.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45513].
  {panel}

*Use case:*

We allow some external users to access our internal company Confluence. This is done using a LDAP user directory, so new external users are synchronized automatically when they have a special Confluence right. Sometimes we don't grant access to any space but plan to do so later. So some users have access to our Confluence but shouldn't have access to any Space. But if they login, the Welcome screen forces users to watch a Space. It seems to be if they aren't allowed to see any Space, the Welcome screen chooses a random Space for suggestion. The user can't skip the process, so he watches the space he shouldn't be able to see. From now on he can see the space but isn't listed in the permission setting for that Space. So one can't also detect or remove the permission.

 

*Steps to reproduce:*
 * Have the Welcome screen enabled (for all modules)
 * Add fresh user to Confluence
 * Assign the user to a group without default space permissions (global permissions "can use", but not listed under default space permissions)
 * Login as that user
 * Skip intro
 * Skip also next page (thats the personal space page setup? not sure but also not important for this)
 * Check the suggested Space for watching
 * Open that space

 

*Actual result:*
 * User can see a space
 * User is not listed when checking the space permissions

 

*Expected result:*
 * 3rd welcome screen is skipped because he can't watch any space
 * User can't see any space

 

We had this issue multiple times, I can not guarantee that users see what they are meant to see.

 

*Workaround for +future situations+:*
 * Skip welcome screen ([https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/how-to-skip-the-welcome-action-for-new-users-in-confluence-777016501.html)]

 

*Workaround for +past situations:+*
 * ???

 

I need something like:
 * Find out which users can see spaces they shouldn't see
 * Remove their access to those spaces

Our Confluence version is 5.9.8.
fields.summary: Welcome screen for users without any permissions grants access to random space

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45483].
  {panel}

Your documentation is full of marketing garbage. It thinks it's being friendly but when you use too many words and sell me on something I'm already using, that's not friendly. It's annoying. Plus, it takes forever to get the answers I'm looking for because they are not the primary purpose of the writing. 

Here's an example from your Pages and Blogs documentation. I went there when I was looking for how to create a page that hangs off a main page. Pages and Blogs sounded like a reasonable place to start. Here's what I got:
"When you create any content in Confluence - whether it's taking down some quick [notes from a meeting|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/meeting-notes-blueprint-329975386.html], writing a [requirements page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/product-requirements-blueprint-329975392.html], or letting your teammates know about the company's latest marketing push - you'll either be creating it as a [page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/create-and-edit-pages-139476.html] or a [blog post|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/blog-posts-834222533.html]. You may be shocked to know that this page you're reading now, is, in fact, a Confluence page!

Pages and blog posts are the two things that allow you to capture and share information in Confluence, and which one you use depends on what you want to do with your content. If you want the information to last, and possibly evolve over time, then you likely want to create a page; if the information is specific mainly to the current time-frame, and isn't going to change over time, then you'll most likely want to create it as a blog post. These aren't hard-and-fast rules; they're just pointers to give you a place to start."

Here's a rewrite that's actually aimed at people who are looking for answers, not friends or marketing garbage. 

 

"When you create any content in Confluence you are creating a [page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/create-and-edit-pages-139476.html] or a [blog post|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/blog-posts-834222533.html].  For instance, the page you're reading now is a Confluence page.

Create a page when you want the information to last, and possibly evolve over time.

Create a blog post if the information is time-specific and will not change over time.

These aren't hard-and-fast rules; they're just pointers to give you a place to start."

 

See how I did that? I put the answers right where everyone can see them instead of burying it in a torrent of bullshit. Oops! Can I say bullshit?

I just did!

Carl Yorke
fields.summary: please hire real technical writers

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-45381].
  {panel}

We're trying to deploy Confluence by automating the installation. We need a way to script the entire process from scratch all the way up to a working and fully configured Confluence instance. I'm using Ansible for this task, but the same problem exists for all similar tools (Puppet, Chef, Salt, etc).

The *installation* can be done programmatically. But the *setup* part involves clicking through a wizard web interface to select the installation type, put in the license, configure the database, etc: https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/confluence-setup-guide-135691.html.
This prevents proper automation.

I know that Stash exposes a REST API that can be used to automate some of these steps (for instance the license: https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/stash/3.11.3/stash-rest.html#idp1739392), but the Confluence REST API doesn't expose anything like this.

So at this point our devops process is stuck and we need to manually click through a wizard, which is a real pain.

Confluence needs to be able to get deployed without manual intervention.

This can either be done by providing options during install, for instance using a simple configuration file with license, install type, plugins to include.

Or extend the REST API to handle these.
fields.summary: Automated deployment
